title: Mohammad Haroon
text:
<a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Mohammad Haroon (<a href="Urdu">Urdu</a>:محمد ہارون), , is a retired <a href="Three-star%20rank">three-star</a> rank <a href="admiral">admiral</a> in the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> and a defence analyst, writing in the "<a href="Express%20Tribune">Express Tribune</a>".
In 2005, Admiral Haroon was notably superseded by Vice-Admiral <a href="Afzal%20Tahir">Afzal Tahir</a> to the appointment of <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">Chief of Naval Staff</a> as a <a href="Four%20star%20admiral">four-star admiral</a> but continued his service until he reached to his set retirement date.
Biography.
Mohammad Haroon was born in <a href="Lahore">Lahore</a>, <a href="Punjab%2C%20Pakistan">Punjab</a>, initially belonging a village, <a href="Alowal">Alowal</a>, located in <a href="Toba%20Tek%20Singh%20District">District Toba Tek Singh</a>, into a military family; his father served in the <a href="Pakistan%20Army">Pakistan Army</a>, retiring as <a href="major">major</a>. After his matriculation, he joined the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> in <a href="Sub%20Lieutenant">Sub-Lieutenant</a> in 1967, and went to attend the <a href="Britannia%20Naval%20College">Britannia Naval College</a> where he graduated as <a href="Submarine">underwater</a> specialist in 1970, gaining <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commission</a> as <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lieutenant</a> in the Navy.
<a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Haroon participated well in the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20wars">western front</a> of the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20war%20of%201971">third war</a> with <a href="India">India</a> in 1971, serving in the <a href="%3AHangor-class%20submarine%20%281970%29">PNS Mangro</a>. Before participating, Lt. Haroon did a brief duty in East Pakistan's coastal areas in 1969–70. After the war, his career in the Navy progressed well, eventually <a href="Commander%20%28rank%29">Cdr.</a> Haroon commanding a submarine squadron.
He was educated, and graduated in the <a href="war%20studies">war studies</a> degree from the <a href="National%20Defence%20University%2C%20Pakistan">National Defence University</a> in <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> in the 1970s. He also went to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> to attend, and graduated from the <a href="Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a> in <a href="Rhode%20Island%2C%20United%20States">Rhode Island</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. Upon returning to Pakistan, he briefly served in the <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> as <a href="Assistant%20Chief%20of%20the%20Naval%20Staff">ACNS (Plans)</a>. As <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Captain</a> in the Navy, he commanded a destroyer and three <a href="Hangor-class%20submarine%20%281968%29">Hangor-class submarine</a> as his command assignments.
In 1987-90s, Captain Haroon was selected by the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Pakistan%29">Ministry of Defence</a> (MoD) for a diplomatic assignment, and briefly served as <a href="Military%20attach%C3%A9">naval attaché</a> at the <a href="High%20Commission%20of%20Pakistan%2C%20New%20Delhi">High Commission of Pakistan</a> in <a href="New%20Delhi">New Delhi</a>, <a href="India">India</a>.
In 1996, <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Cdre</a> Haroon served in the <a href="JS%20HQ%20%28Pakistan%29">Joint Staff HQ</a> in <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a> as directing staff of war wing, and later served as director joint training.
In 2000–01, <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Cdre</a> Haroon was promoted to <a href="Two-star%20rank">two-star</a> rank, and Rear-Admiral Haroon took over as the commander of the Submarine Command (COMSUBS), actively participating in deploying the submarines during the <a href="2001-2002%20India-Pakistan%20standoff">military standoff</a> with <a href="India">India</a> in 2001. In 2002, Rear-Admiral Haroon was appointed as commander of Karachi (COMKAR), having received the <a href="German%20Navy">German Navy</a> warship in <a href="Karachi%20coast">Karachi coast</a> which paid the farewell visit to Pakistan Navy. In 2003, Rear-Admiral Haroon was promoted to three-star assignment in the Navy.
In 2004–05, <a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Haroon was appointed as a senior <a href="Fleet%20Commander">fleet commander</a> of Pakistan Navy's Fleet (COMPAK). On 7 November 2005, Vice-Admiral Haroon was appointed as <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29%23Vice%20Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff">Vice Chief of Naval Staff</a>.
In 2005, Vice-Admiral Haroon was notably superseded by Vice-Admiral <a href="Afzal%20Tahir">Afzal Tahir</a> to the four-star rank appointment and as the <a href="Four%20star%20admiral">four-star admiral</a> in the Navy. This promotion for Admiral <a href="Afzal%20Tahir">Afzal Tahir</a> marked with controversy that <a href="Afzal%20Tahir">Admiral Tahir</a> had to clarify his working relationship with Vice-Admiral Haroon, stressing "no differences with Admiral Haroon and had family terms with him." Vice-Admiral Haroon served to complete his tenureship under Admiral Tahir, <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">Chief of Naval Staff</a>, and was eventually retired in 2007.
After retiring from the Navy, Admiral Haroon was invited to be appointed as <a href="Rector%20%28academia%29">Rector</a> of the <a href="Bahria%20University">Bahria University</a> in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a>, and is a regular columnist for country's political correspondents on national security and defence analysis.
